Answer: A: He begins by stressing the cost and energy burden of today’s AI and the CPU–RAM communication bottleneck, then pivots to memristors that store and process in the same place, built as neurons and synapses. The slides reinforce this with “BUILDING THE WORLD’S mostEFFICIENT, BRAIN-INSPIRED_CHIP” and a split-screen diagram of the memristor next to a GEMESYS chip. He then promises 100x speed/efficiency, envisions every processor carrying their chip, and ends by arguing for truly personal models that learn on-device like a phone understanding one person’s speech.

The speaker starts by acknowledging the limitations of current AI systems, which leads him to propose a solution using memristors. This shows his thought process developing from recognizing a problem to proposing a potential solution. As the presentation progresses, he emphasizes the efficiency and scalability of his proposed solution, which further supports the idea that his stance has evolved from diagnosing AI inefficiency to proposing a hardware remedy. Additionally, his emphasis on personal models that learn on-device aligns with his vision for the future of AI use.

This sets a positive tone for the rest of the presentation. As the pitch progresses, it moves towards discussing the commercial aspects of their product, including revenue streams and partnerships.
